title: Wednesday, 2nd January 2019
bodyHTML:

Curious does HoF not just lover to the top end* of Sports Direct? I assumed that was where dear Mike was going with his high street shopping vision*yes, yes...
red heard that there isnt much movement from some of the operators re rent, so some big sites are closing. this was just after xmas, i dont know if anything has changed from likes of intu and others
BE11:20am

Chinese manufacturing very poor for December. We can blame trade tensions, because just because it's a new year there's no reason to find new things to say.

BE11:20am

RBC:

11:20 am
BE11:20am

2019 has kicked off in much the same way that 2018 ended – with weakness and elevated volatility in global equities. US futures are 1.5% lower overnight and our Risk Aversion Thermometer is well over one standard deviation risk averse (10.3). US 10yr yields are at 11 month lows. In FX this has had the predictable effect of supporting JPY (109.05) and hitting AUD (0.7010) and other risky currencies. The only real news overnight was more weak Chinese data (see China below). USD is flat (DXY terms), but the year starts with a widespread consensus for USD weakness as the main theme. Whilst we do not buy into this consensus, we also note, as we have identified in previous years, that FX markets have tendency to overshoot in January (in either direction) and reverse in the rest of Q1, at least in certain currency pairs. There is no key data or speakers in the remainder of today, but news-flow picks up tomorrow.

China: The Caixin manufacturing PMI mirrored the fall in the official index (released on Monday). The headline index fell below 50 (49.7) for the first time in 18 months and we note that the export orders series in both surveys remain very weak, consistent with our Asia strategist’s view that exports are set to weaken materially in the coming months as the effect of front-loading unwinds.

Forester @red you are right. Ashley is right about one thing - the freeholders need to wake up and smell the coffee. If the rent was £1 all the units would be full of shops of some sorts, whether vape shops or whatever. As ever, just a question of price.
BE11:22am

And HSBC for a bit more detail.

BE11:22am

The Caixin manufacturing PMI fell to 49.7 in December from 50.2 in November, dipping into
contractionary territory for the first time since May 2017. The data breakdown points to weak demand,
both externally and domestically. The new orders sub-index contracted in December, after remaining
above the 50 level for two and a half years. The new export orders sub-index remained in contraction,
although the reading improved modestly from November. Meanwhile, price pressures moderated, in line
with softer activity and falling oil prices. On a positive note, production registered a slight expansion,
while expectations around future output also improved.
We expect manufacturing activity to improve gradually in the months ahead, as policy makers continue
to reflate the economy. At the annual Central Economic Work Conference (CEWC) held in December
2018, authorities reiterated their plans to significantly cut taxes and fees in 2019, while continuing to
selectively ease funding conditions for private firms and take more concrete steps towards structural
reforms and improving market access. Meanwhile, the PBoC also launched the Targeted Medium Term Lending Facility
(TMLF), with a lower lending rate to support bank lending to private companies and SMEs. Combined
with further Required Reserve Ratio cuts–we expect 200 bps of RRR cuts this year–these measures
should help support a recovery in the manufacturing sector.

chopper bear must say the sports direct shop i saw in reyjekavik yesterday was quite the contrast
red @Forestertough one as drops in rent mean asset write down. of course mkt has written down assets but officially they need to be done on the books. some sites are worth a lot lot less. they want to avoid the domino effect and are all holding firm for now, but you feel eventually they need to give on the rents.

http://en.people.c...90000-9533881.html

China must and will be united, which is an inevitable requirement for the historical rejuvenation of the Chinese nation in the new era.

BE11:24am

RA happy new year everyone
BE11:24am

Here's Citi.

Forester @chopper https://www.thisismoney.co.uk/money/news/article-3555403/Panama-Papers-reveal-link-Sports-Direct-Icelanders-centre-financial-meltdown.html
BE11:24am

The speech seemed to have moved the market – The gathering had been largely taken as a nonevent by the market, but we believe President Xi’s message turned out to be stronger than expected. We think it was one factor behind the declines of the HK/CN stock markets on the day, along with the broad-based PMI weakness in Dec and the negative industrial profit growth in Nov. Despite the market downturn, military-related stocks rallied among the A-shares.
Cross-strait relations could be one source of market volatility in the New Year – The issue may become more sensitive, because: (1) 2019 will be the 70th anniversary of the establishment of the “new China” by the Communist Party. China will hold a large-scale military parade in Oct. (2) Increasing US-China tensions may inject more uncertainty into cross-strait relations. (3) Taiwan will hold its presidential election in early 2020. While raising market volatility, cross-strait dynamics will likely continue to help drive the ongoing development of China's military industry.

Ophir Energy PLC (OPHR:LSE): Last: 47.25, up 11.55 (+32.35%), High: 50.80, Low: 46.60, Volume: 6.42m
Phil Happy New Year to all.
11:29 am

Attracting a possible cash offer from Medco, the Indonesian thing.

Shinshin @rw42 alphabeds.co.uk
BE11:30am

Question now is, how much?

Forester @rw42 expecting a New Year bounce?
BE11:31am

Somewhere close to NAV, probably, but NAV here is an art rather than a science.

11:31 am
BE11:31am

Jefferies:

BE11:31am

News that Ophir & Medco are in discussions should not come as a surprise. Interim CEO Alan Booth's comments that "you build a business that's valuable, so it becomes valuable for the trade" (1H18 results) are proving prescient. We believe a valuation in line with our Core NAV 52p/sh could be achievable due to less conviction as to the strategic value of OPHR (in contrast to, for example, Faroe Petroleum's (FPM LN, Buy 190p PT) strategic value to DNO).

BE11:32am

Our 52p/sh price target for OPHR is based on Core NAV of $506m including ex-Salamander producing assets ("Bualuang" oil Thailand, "Kerenden" gas Indonesia) and recently acquired ex-Santos production assets, the most material being a 31.9% stake in the Vietnam "Chim Sao" field. Group production for 2018 proforma the Santos assets is expected to be c.27,500boed.

11:32 am
BE11:33am

Stifel go higher.

FATDAZ @rw42 have to say very pleased with the bed / mattress headboard combo we bought a year ago from Bensons
BE11:33am

Our 66p price target equates to an enterprise value of c. $730M assuming $100m net debt year end 2019; we believe this is the minimum price that shareholders should accept - assuming a formal offer is made - given this includes a $100M liability for G&A costs which we think can be largely eliminated, and does not include either the recent exploration success on the Sampang PSC or the updated guidance on the year end 2018 net debt position of c. $65M vs c. $110M previously.

BE11:34am

Worth noting that the 66p is based on oil at $70 a barrel.

11:35 am
BE11:35am

Brent's, what, $53 today?

BE11:36am

Take that back to $60 a barrel and you get 49p NAV.

Excel Developer Oil is close to a bottom , says Tony Cerescenzi from Pimco
BE11:36am

This news has wider implications for the E&P sector too, we believe - a validation that the sector does look undervalued to energy industry competitors, given its high free cash flow yield (greater than 10% on our estimates), the sector trading at an average discount to our NAV valuations of c. 40%, and a number of companies with significant upsides to target prices from stock-specific drivers and not commodity prices.

11:37 am
BE11:37am

(@Excel: if I understand geology, it's usually below the bottom.)

BE11:37am

Citi.

BE11:38am

[W]e expected a pick-up in M&A activity in 2019 as Mid-Cap E&Ps looked to merge or acquire assets to increase their scale and relevance. The acquisition of Ophir would not only add to Medco’s Indonesian operations, which is currently Medco’s principal focus area, but also expand
Medco’s E&P activities in South-East Asia. Medco is listed on the Jakarta Stock Exchange with a market cap of c. US$900m.

RA apparently many oil producers say below 45 its not worth producing?
11:38 am
BE11:38am

We value Ophir’s core assets at 42p/share (assuming US$55/bbl long-term and a 10% discount rate). However this includes 3p/share risked for Ophir’s Fortuna LNG development project. The viability of which remains uncertain. Our core NAV would rise to 52p/share at US$65/bbl long-term (or 48p/share excluding Fortuna LNG). Our core NAV does not include any value for Ophir’s contingent resources identified across its South-East Asia operations, which we risk at 8p/share in our base NAV.

red @Excel Developerwhat is almost certain, if oil heads str8 dwn in 2019, it is v likely to move back to 45-50 min by year end.
Shinshin @excel great item in paper today on China fuel cells. Think $50 may not be the low.
BE11:38am

We believe the challenge in the negotiations will be what value to ascribe to Ophir’s Fortuna FLNG project in Equatorial Guinea and Ophir’s contingent gas resources offshore Tanzania. In Equatorial Guinea, Ophir and its partners have struggled to secure project financing for the Fortuna FLNG project and its licence expired on 31st December 2018. Ophir is still awaiting a response from the EG government with regards to its request for an extension of the Block R licence. Ophir expects an update in January. In Tanzania, Ophir and its partners have discovered material offshore gas resources, but the timing and viability of a large scale LNG development project remains very uncertain.

On the idea that Europe-to-North America's the most fragile of the markets, and that UK has all the obvious risks.

BE11:46am

What's perhaps more interesting is Citi's argument that IAG is desperate to expand beyond the BA franchise so will be buying something big quite soon.

BE11:47am

Their consolidation scenarios are worth going through in detail. I'll ignore scenario one because it involves nothing much happening.

red any info on new italian bank failure?
11:47 am
BE11:47am

Scenario 2 assumes that the top four airline groups will control c.65% of the intra-European market share by 2025. This scenario hypothesizes Air France-KLM (with its current backing of China Eastern and Delta) buying both EasyJet & Flybe, IAG combining with Norwegian & (alliance partner) Finnair, as well as Ryanair buying (the very similar, albeit geographically diverse) Wizz and Lufthansa purchasing Alitalia & (Star Alliance compatriot) SAS.

Excel Developer Italy inching towards recession , always bad for banks.
BE11:48am

Scenario 3: assumes that the top four airline groups will control c.67% of the intra-European market share by 2025. This scenario hypothesizes IAG buying EasyJet, Lufthansa purchasing SAS, Air France-KLM combining with (its old stake) Alitalia and Norwegian Air Shuttle, as well as Ryanair only being ‘allowed’ (by the EU’s arguable conservatism and interventionism) to buy smaller tail companies (e.g. as per the recent Laudamotion takeover).

BE11:48am

So, that boils down to four key potential deals.

11:48 am
BE11:49am

1. IAG & Norwegian Air Shuttle
2. IAG & EasyJet
3. Air France-KLM & EasyJet
4. Ryanair & Wizz

Excel Developer Some Thomas Hale, https://ftalphaville.ft.com/2018/08/13/1534151830000/Italian-banks-and-the-problem-of-tightly-knit-politics/
Shinshin Hard to see BA/EZ getting through competition review
BE11:49am

Leverage is clearly the problem with option 1, because Norwegian is massively in debt and appears to pay passengers to use it.

BE11:50am

Which moves us down to option 2.

11:50 am
BE11:50am

EasyJet would offer IAG an additional +40% of Gatwick, +44% of Luton and strength in Amsterdam and CDG. Simply put, while it does not have the diversity and breadth of Norwegian, We believe EasyJet, with its unique slot network, could potentially breathe new life into British Airway’s UK growth prospects.

BE11:51am

And on the CMA ..... maybe not.

BE11:51am

The most significant pushback on a hypothetical merger of IAG & EasyJet is the risk of anti-trust fall-out in the London market. We disagree on this point and note that a combined IAG & EasyJet entity would still be less than c.50% of the total London market. Notably, this combined market share would be less than AF-KLM’s 50% market share in Paris and Lufthansa’s 63% in Frankfurt.

11:53 am
BE11:53am

Air France-KLM also makes sense as an Easyjet buyer, particularly if you consider the potential Vinci ownership of CDG & Orly and the likelihood that it'll want budget traffic growth.

BE11:54am

AF buying EasyJet would be "an act of monopolistic behavior that would not have been seen since Lufthansa bought Air Berlin," Citi says.

easyJet plc (EZJ:LSE): Last: 1,093, down 12.5 (-1.13%), High: 1,132, Low: 1,078, Volume: 294.41k

MonkeyTrader Leverage at Norwegian is a bit of an odd issue - NAS suffers from low equity and not an overt amount of debt. The debt only comes into play when it takes delivery of the brand new aircraft it took options down on. IAG would love those new aircraft - so maybe IAG just sits around and sees what happens.

An excellent starting point for understanding how Hilco works comes via the insolvency docs tied to its shutdown of HMV Canada: https://www.richte...eiver-20170609.pdf

Blank canvas thanks for a bright start to the new year. Welcome back BE
Excel Developer @Bryce: welcome back. I hope you get a helper. Cheers, bye.
Flaneur @Forester 11:21 - on freeholders and rents.... its all knee bone conected to the thigh bone, the thig bones connected to the hip bone, teh hip bones connected to....etc....In the end comm prop valuations and rents are connected to 10 years or QE coming home to roost.
BE12:02pm

The UK entities are incredibly complicated, packed full of inter-company loans, and making considerable use of abbreviated reporting rules.

Flaneur *of
BE12:03pm

It also seems under-reported that HMV hasn't gone into administration. HMV (Retail) has.

12:05 pm
BE12:05pm

The Hilco entity that loaned HMV £8m at 8% interest isn't in admin, and neither are the many subsidiary companies that raked out charges from the core for brand licencing, website development and that kind of thing.

BE12:06pm

Do have a scan of that Canadian doc. It's fascinating, in its way.
